awd_titl_txt: Encoding the pore landscapes of nanoporous materials: a data-driven approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline materials, made from metal clusters tethered together by organic linking molecules, that exhibit nano-sized pores connected by channels. Gas molecules selectively adsorb into these sponge-like materials allowing MOFs to efficiently separate or purify mixtures of gases encountered in industry. Choosing different metals or linking molecules gives hundreds of thousands of possible MOFs combinations. How does one find the right match between a desired molecular separation and the type of MOF to do the job? This project aims to develop a computational approach that uses images of the 3D pore structures of hundreds of thousands of MOFs to quantitatively describe the pores inside MOFs. Serving as a fingerprint of pore shape, these descriptions are useful for (i) grouping together MOFs that have similar pore structures and (ii) predicting the ability of a MOF to separate chemically similar molecules effectively. By computationally finding the right MOF for the job instead of experimentally testing them all (a time- and resource-intensive process), this proposed research is expected to accelerate the deployment of MOFs for gas separations, thereby saving energy, making goods cheaper to produce, and reducing pollution. The investigators will also mentor high school and undergraduate minority students in summer research programs at Oregon State University to encourage these students in computational science.

Nanoporous materials, such as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), have the ability to selectively adsorb gas molecules which make them industrially relevant to gas separations. Owing to their modular synthesis, MOFs are highly tunable and offer a vast chemical space in which to optimize gas separation properties. Because the pore geometry within a MOF strongly influences its adsorptive selectivity, mathematical characterization will greatly improve efficiency in investigating MOF structures. This project will design a deep convolutional autoencoder to encode the pore structures of MOFs into low-dimensional, information-rich, latent vector representations, i.e.  fingerprints. Three-dimensional, computational images of the porosity of over 200,000 MOFs will serve as training data for the autoencoder. This research will determine the optimal architecture, regularization scheme, and loss function to coax the autoencoder to extract the salient features of pore structures in MOFs in a translation- and rotation-invariant manner. The machine-learned fingerprints of MOFs will be practically useful for (i) building a classification or regression model of adsorptive selectivity and (ii) by defining a meaningful distance metric, identifying candidates exhibiting the most similar pore structures to a promising but suboptimal "lead" material to fine-tune its adsorptive selectivity in a "lead optimization" strategy for materials discovery. To demonstrate the practical utility of the latent vector representations, the predictiveness of simulated adsorptive selectivity for several industrially-relevant separations will be assessed. Deployment of the trained autoencoder to encode the salient features of pore structures of MOFs into fingerprints will accelerate the discovery and deployment of nanoporous materials that display the optimal pore structure to target the adsorption of a particular gas species, thereby enabling separation.

por.por_cntn:
For our NSF Project that spanned four years, we (a team comprised of a computer science professor, chemical engineering professor, two computer science PhD students, two chemical engineering PhD students, and three undergraduate researchers) worked on developing machine learning models that can learn to predict the properties of materials and molecules on a computer, given examples (data).

A few key outcomes of our work, largely disseminated through peer-reviewed publications that you can read online, are:
- training a data-driven model that can predict if two aqueous solutions of compounds will form a two-phase system upon mixing. These predictions are useful for separations in biotechnology.
- writing a tutorial on a probabalistic technique to solve inverse problems, using the following intuitive example: suppose a cold lime fruit was taken out of your refrigerator some time ago. We walk into the kitchen and measure the temperature of the lime. From that measurement, can we infer the temperature of your refrigerator? This is an inverse problem, and it is interesting because the answer is highly sensitive to measurement noise. This means we must quantify uncertainty in the solution to it. We actually conducted this experiment and used the data for our tutorial.  
- developed a machine learning classifier to predict toxicity of pesticides to honey bees, based on walks along the molecular graphs representing the pesticides. This prediction task is important for the development of pesticides that are not toxic to bees, important for pollination of many crops we rely upon.
- inspired by recommendation systems at Netflix, Spotify, and Amazon, we trained a recommendation system that can recommend different materials for different applications. We used a matrix factorization algorithm that is commonly used in commercial recommendation systems. Instead of ratings for products, the entries of our matrix are adsorption properties of nanoporous materials.
- developed and released open-source software to add functional groups to crystal structure models. This is a common task for high-throughput computational screening of materials, where one seeks to build a library of hypothetical materials with different chemistry, then screen them for a certain property using molecular simulations.  
- illustrated a technique called Bayesian optimization for the discovery of nanoporous materials with desired adsorption properties. This technique combines machine learning and decision-making algorithms under uncertainty to rapidly, i.e. with the minimal number of experiments, find the optimal material. 
- developed a mathematical method to curate the optimal combination of sensing elements for a gas sensor array, by viewing it as an inverse problem and inspecting how the solution to this inverse problem depends on inevitable measurement noise that contaminates the response of the sensing elements.
- pointed out an analogy between mathematical models of the spread of disease such as COVID-19 and autocatalytic reactions happening in a chemical reactor. This strong mathematical analogy is helpful for bridging the fields of chemical reactor and epidemic modeling. 
- trained a graph neural network that assigns charges to the atoms of porous crystals, which is an important step for molecular simulation of adsorption in porous crystals. In the big picture, we could design such materials on the computer, for tasks in separating, storing, and sensing gases.
